#Text=Paul Boghossian
#Text=Not to be confused with Peter Boghossian .
#Text=Paul Artin Boghossian ( /bəˈɡoʊziən/ ; born 1957 ) is an American philosopher .
#Text=He is Silver professor of philosophy at New York University , where he was Chair of the Department for ten years ( 1994 – 2004 ) . [ 2 ]
#Text=His research interests include epistemology , the philosophy of mind , and the philosophy of language .
#Text=He is Director of the New York Institute of Philosophy and Distinguished Research Professor of Philosophy at the University of Birmingham . [ 3 ]
#Text=Education and career
#Text=Boghossian is of Armenian ancestry . [ 4 ]
#Text=Boghossian earned his B.S. in physics at Trent University in 1976 , [ 5 ] and his Ph.D. in philosophy at Princeton University in 1987 .

#Text=In addition to his current position at NYU , he was a professor of philosophy at the University of Michigan at Ann Arbor from 1984 until 1992 , and has also been a visiting professor at Princeton University .
#Text=He has previously held research fellowships from the National Endowment for the Humanities , Magdalen College , Oxford , the University of London , and the Australian National University .
#Text=He is a fellow of the New York Institute for the Humanities .
#Text=He is on the editorial board of the journals Philosophical Studies and Philosophers ' Imprint .
#Text=In postmodern circles , Boghossian is known for his response to the Sokal hoax . [ 6 ]
#Text=Boghossian also serves as a member of the Scientific Advisory Board for the World Knowledge Dialogue Foundation . [ 7 ]
#Text=His book Fear of Knowledge won a Choice Award as an outstanding Academic Book of 2006 .
#Text=In 2012 , he was elected a Fellow of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences . [ 8 ]
#Text=Philosophical work
#Text=In his early work , Boghossian was a trenchant critic of naturalistic theories of content .

#Text=Much of his later work , including his book Fear of Knowledge , criticizes various forms of relativism , especially epistemic relativism , which claims that knowledge and reason are fundamentally cultural or subjective rather than objective .

#Text=In his article ' Blind Reasoning ' , Boghossian argues that we are blind to our reasons for justifying our methods of inference ( the epitome of a method of inference is taken to be modus ponens . )

#Text=Rejecting both Simple Inferential Externalism for its inconsistency and Simple Inferential Internalism because it is difficult to accept , he opts for a third and new form of " rational insight " .

column1: #Text=This paper , in conjunction with an ongoing correspondence between Boghossian and Crispin Wright , is part of a project to defend against epistemic relativism .
#Text=Selected publications
#Text=Books
#Text=Content and Justification : Philosophical Papers , Oxford University Press , 2008 .
#Text=Fear of Knowledge : Against Relativism and Constructivism , Oxford University Press , 2006 . [ 9 ]
#Text=Articles
#Text=" How Are Objective Epistemic Reasons Possible ? "
#Text=in Philosophical Studies , Dec 2001 , pp.340 – 380 .
#Text=" Inference and Insight , " in Philosophy and Phenomenological Research , November , 2001 , pp.633 – 641 .
#Text=" On Hearing the Music in the Sound , " in The Journal of Aesthetics and Art Criticism ( 2002 ) .
#Text=" The Gospel of Relaxation " ( review of The Metaphysical Club by Louis Menand ) , The New Republic , September 2001 .
#Text=" What is Social Construction ? " in Times Literary Supplement , February 23 , 2001 , pp.6 – 8 .
#Text=New Essays on the A Priori ( co-edited with Christopher Peacocke ) , Oxford University Press 2000 .
#Text=" Knowledge of Logic , " in New Essays on the A Priori , Oxford University Press 2000 .
#Text=" Analyticity , " in Bob Hale and Crispin Wright ( eds . ) : The Philosophy of Language ( Oxford : Basil Blackwell , 1997 ) , pp.331 – 368 .
#Text=Media
#Text=' The Secrets of the World ' : Debate with philosophers Rebecca Roache and Hilary Lawson , and author Rupert Sheldrake .
#Text=' The Word and the World ' : Debate with philosopher Ray Monk and novelist Joanna Kavenna .
#Text=' Strange New Worlds ' : Debate with literary critic Terry Eagleton and Chocolat author Joanne Harris .
